title-group.article-title: Hydrogeochemical evaluation of groundwater in Deccan Volcanic Province, Maharashtra, India through GIS and statistical techniques

abstract.p: In the present work statistical techniques and GIS approach has been used to understand the hydrogeochemical evaluation of groundwater and its influencing factors in the region of Deccan Volcanic Province (DVP), Maharashtra, India. A network of 60 groundwater sampling stations was identified by considering geology, geomorphology, land use pattern etc. The groundwater samples were collected subsequently for pre-monsoon (PRM) and post-monsoon (POM) seasons of the year 2022. Hydrochemical analysis include pH, EC, TDS, cations (Ca, Mg, Na, K), anions (CO3, HCO3, NO3, SO4, Cl, F) were performed by following standard analytical protocols of American Public Health Association (APHA). As per the Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS) for drinking, the parameters like pH, TH, NO3, F and K are surpassed the threshold limits in both the seasons. Also recognize the geological formations with different lithologies from the study region to identify the geogenic causes of contamination. Box plots are prepared for better illustration of average, median, minimum and maximum values for various water ions. Pollution Index of Groundwater (PIG) tool is used to classify the water quality for beneficial use and results depicted that only 1.67% sample from POM season indicates very high pollution. Spatial distribution maps of PIG are prepared in GIS platform to demarcate the different zones of groundwater pollution and observed that south-westerly part having more groundwater pollution than other regions. Statistical techniques like Correlation Matrix (CM), Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and Cluster Analysis (CA) used to know the degree of association among hydrogeochemical data and their collective influence on groundwater quality. Piper trilinear plot has been used to categorize the dominant water facies and types of water in the study region, and results shows that 100% samples having calcium-magnesium and bicarbonate-carbonate types. Bivariate plots for major ions were prepared to signify the natural and anthropogenic factors which alter groundwater quality. Gibb’s diagram suggested that 98.34% samples influenced by mechanism of rock domain and only 1.66% sample shows evaporation dominance. Wilcox plot suggested that majority of the groundwater samples are fall in good to moderate categories for agriculture use; while, 95% and 75% samples in excellent to good zone and 5% and 23.34% samples show good to permissible zones in PRM and POM seasons respectively.

sec.title: Supplementary Information
sec.p: The online version contains supplementary material available at 10.1038/s41598-025-17782-9.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The natural resources like air, water and soil are very crucial to sustain the life on the earth planet. However, these resources have been rapidly depleting due to natural and anthropogenic phenomenon like global warming, climate change and population pressure. Recently, the growing population in rural and urban areas and their dependency on these resources have been increased fold worldwide. However, due to human interference and over exploitation of these natural resources the dynamics of earth ecosystem is progressively affecting. Water is one of the most considerable substances that strongly influence the human life and essential in land shaping and climate regulating1. Generally, water is characterized as saline water, freshwater, groundwater are very dominant resources for life sustenance. Approximately 70% of the earth’s planet freshwater is stored in glaciers and only 3% of the earth’s water is as freshwater while, the remaining 97% is saline water. Groundwater accomplish around half of the irrigation and drinking water demands in worldwide2–4. The water chemistry is a very dynamic, modified and largely meticulous by its interaction with soil, rock, precipitation, climate etc5.

Groundwater is widely used for drinking, agriculture, industry and domestic purposes6. Out of the major rising consumption of water through different water resources, groundwater is one of the important one due to its natural state and least relative pathogenic risk as compared to surface water resources. In recent period, by widespread urbanisation, industrialisation and agricultural, which leads to groundwater pollution and contamination, hence it become crucial to important analyses of groundwater quality in terms of different uses7. Water excellence and calamities are important apprehensions in many areas of different nations, particularly in semi-arid areas to mitigate regular water scarcities8. In India, the annual exploitable groundwater and surface water resources are projected as 396 km3 and 690 km3 per year respectively9. Groundwater has gradually developed as the major support and backbone of India’s irrigation and drinking water security with its quality and quantity. It is estimated that 50% groundwater meet the urban water supply and 85% in rural water supply and 62% of irrigation10. In Maharashtra, aquifers from Deccan volcanic provinces are the important foundation for groundwater potential and movement11. Many previous studies on hydro-geochemistry have been performed in various parts of the country by Pawar et al.11, Brindha and Elango12, Tiwari et al.13, Gaikwad et al.14 and assessed the possible source of contamination through geogenic or anthropogenic inputs. The groundwater movement takes place through fine pores present in aquifer material or in the soil zone through rock media which leads to rock-water interaction15. Most of the common mineral elements which cause alkalinity are calcium carbonate, which may be originated in calcite and leached through the soil16. The worsening of groundwater quality is due to fast growing expansion and industrial development in the world17. Therefore, to understand the groundwater chemistry is critical fundamental mechanism for analysis and quality evaluation18. Geology of any area plays a vital role to control the groundwater geochemistry and types of lithology present in the respective study region signify the rock dominance which persuade on groundwater composition19. Hydrochemistry may alter owed by anthropogenic inputs like irrigation, chemical fertilizers, inappropriate sanitation and waste disposal20.

A pollution index of groundwater (PIG) was proposed by Subba Rao to enumerate the groundwater concentrations superiority towards measures with respect to their drinking water excellence21. PIG method has been used by many water researchers to facilitate the classification of water quality in a simple way to end users19,22,23. As irrigation point of view, water suitability is assessed by considering hydrochemistry and owing the presence of salinity in water bodies, either on the sub-surface or surface, the contamination of soil increased during irrigations24,25. Statistical analysis like CM, PCA, CA etc., is useful to demonstrate the association among the water quality variables and recognise the affecting parameters from natural or anthropogenic inputs7,26–31. Recently, Geographical Information System (GIS) become important tool for preparation of spatial distribution maps for better understanding of groundwater contaminated zones. Piper Trilinear diagram is used to know the dominant water types and hydrochemical facies32. Gibb’s plot is used to identify the groundwater quality controlling mechanism through rock, evaporation and precipitation33. Chloro-Alkaline Indices (CAI) is used to study the hydrochemical variations and composition of groundwater along its movement34,35. A Chloro-alkaline index of samples gives idea about chemical process between lithology and groundwater, suggested two chloro alkaline indices (CA-I and CA-II) for the explanation of ion exchange among host environment and groundwater. Wilcox36 and Richards37 has developed a method which is used to understand the sodium hazards in sub surface water samples for judging the suitability of water for irrigation purpose (EC plots against Na%).

The present work is performed in Aundha Nagnath region of DVP where groundwater has immense importance in rural livelihood and inadequate literature available on groundwater contamination and its associated health risk. In the studied area, groundwater is the primary source for both irrigation and drinking; such investigations play a crucial role for effective resource management. The findings of the work can assist the local authorities by confirming the harmless and hygienic distribution of groundwater. Additionally, the research recognizes problematic aquifers and potential contamination sources, including natural processes like mineral dissolution and human-induced factors such as discharges of domestic waste and agricultural runoff. Wagh et al.38 studied the groundwater geochemistry from the Aundha Nagnath town and results depict that groundwater quality is majorly influenced due to geogenic and anthropogenic inputs. This work will be helpful as baseline information which facilitates for groundwater resources management towards growth, monitoring, handling and sustainability in the study area. Therefore, the work is initiated with following objectives coupled with integration of hydrogeochemical evaluation with GIS and statistical tools: (1) to study the hydrogeochemical evaluation for drinking in season wise (pre-monsoon and post-monsoon) and identifying the affecting parameters that influenced groundwater quality, (2) to ascertain the geological or anthropogenic influence that control hydro-geochemistry through statistical techniques and PIG method, (3) to demarcate the potential polluted groundwater zones and extent of contamination with the help of GIS tools. In view of the above objectives, the experimental design, results and discussions were elaborated in detail in subsequent sections of the manuscript. Hence, the findings of the study will give scientific outcomes for safeguard of groundwater resources for drinking and it desires to understand the chemistry of groundwater for any further interventions if needed.

sec.title: Study area
sec.p: The Aundha Nagnath tehsil is situated at the central-west part of the Hingoli district of Maharashtra state, India. It covers an area of around 813.17 sq. km. The study area is located with the coordinates of 19° 40′ to 19° 71′ N latitude and 76° 86′ to 77° 24′ E longitude, and covered in Survey of India (SOI) toposheet numbers 56 A/11, 12; 56 A/14, 15,16 and 56E/2, 3, 4 on the 1:50,000 scale (Fig. 1). As per the Census of India (2011), the area consists of 122 villages with 35,075 households, and total population of 1,81,148 which include 93,094 males and 88,054 females. In the study area, Sidheshwar dam is constructed on Purna River and its water used for domestic and irrigation through canal system. The major catchment of the study area covered by the Godavari River and its tributaries as Purna, Asna and some small part by Kayadhu river of Penganga catchment associated to drainage network is dendritic to sub dendritic39. Physio-graphically terrain exhibits the elevated mountain of Ajanta hill ranges with Hingoli Plateau of moderate to low towards south slope and elevation ranges from 561 m to 304 m above mean sea level (amsl) and terrain relief is 257 m (amsl) towards south and southwest directions. The climatic conditions are dry except monsoon period and annual average rainfall around 750 to 900 mm mainly received from southwest monsoonal winds40. In the year of 2022, the area receives total rainfall of 1097.3 mm, which is higher than average rainfall of 750 to 900 mm41. The temperature varies from 12.7 to 42 °C in winter and summer seasons; however, hot and dry summers are more extreme than winters42. The eastern, central and southern parts of the tehsil are found black cotton soil with rich plant nutrients and depth range of 1 to 2 m and derived from the parental rock of Deccan Basalt. The dominant crops cultivation in the area are soyabean, sorghum (jowar), pearl millet (bajra), wheat, turmeric, pulses and sugarcanes42. The water level ranges from 3.50 m in post monsoon period to 9.00 m in pre monsoon period40.

caption.p: Map of the study area with sampling locations, shape file extracted from SoI toposheets and modified in ArcGIS 10.8 v software. (Environmental Systems Research Institute, USA. https://www.esri.com)

sec.title: Geology and hydrogeology
sec.p: The area under investigation is the part of the Deccan Volcanic Province (DVP). The lithology in the area is a part of Deccan Trap Supergroup and its litho-units include Deccan Trap Supergroup of Upper Cretaceous to Palaeocene age and inland river valley of alluvial sediments of quaternary age. In the study area, three main geological formations are exposed as Buldhana, Chikhli and Ajanta. The younger formation is Buldhana formation followed by Chikhli formation and Ajanta formation. Buldhana formation comprises of thick pile of basaltic lava flows and a part of Sahyadri Group. The alluvium deposition is comprises of dark to grey clay, silt, sand and gravel in nature43. This formation is occurring in an around eastern region of study area and overlies with Chikhli formation. It is essentially comprises of total seven lava flows of Basalt out of three are from study region. These flows are light grey to sparsely to moderately porphyritic with ropy surface and this layered sequence consisting of ‘aa’ unit. The age of Buldhana formation is Upper Cretaceous to Palaeocene. Chikhli formation occurs in the central north eastern and northern region of the study area and overlies the Ajanta formation and underlies the Buldhana formation. The age of this formation is Upper Cretaceous to Palaeocene and it is consisting of one mixed flow with large aerial extent band is a rhythmically layered sequence of compound ‘pahoehoe’ and ‘aa’ units. Ajanta formation comprises of total five lava flows of basalt out of three are from the study region of mixed nature. This formation occurs in the western, southern and south-western region of study area and overlies the Mahur formation and underlies the Chikhli formation. These rhythmically layered sequence of ‘pahoehoe’ and ‘aa’ flows where the upper part is vesicular and basal part with pipes and amygdules (Fig. 2). In view of hydrogeological perspective, Chikhali formation is the water bearing formation with good permeability and porosity due to highly fractured and weathered rock. The average depth of the collected groundwater samples is in the range of 8–10 m from different sources like dug wells, bore wells and hand pumps. As concern with water table fluctuation, Ajanta formation shows less fluctuation (0–5 feets) observed in 11 samples (Dug well); while high fluctuation found in deeper bore wells (90 feets). Moreover, Chikhali formation shows the dug well (6) with less fluctuations (0 to 5 feets) and high fluctuation is 140 feets in sample number 52. Also, Buldhana formation represents less fluctuation is of (0 to 5 feets) in 3 dug well samples; whereas, deeper bore well (sample number 34) indicates high fluctuation of 170 feets. Apart from the characteristic properties of different lava flows, the topography also plays an important role in groundwater potential of DVP area. The major aquifer area is covered under Ajanta formation and indicates less porous and impervious. The geological cross section map has been prepared along A-B with south-west and north-east orientation for better illustration of different elevated aquifer formations. The thickness of various rock formations varies as Buldhana formation (~ 70 m), Chikhali formation (~ 150 m) and Ajanta formation (~ 100 m) along 31.7 km section of A-B (Fig. 3). The Ajanta formation is comprises of plagioclase, quartz, iddingsite, augite, olivine, calcic feldspar, pyroxene, potash feldspar etc. which get contact with water and dissolved in it44. Ajanta and Buldhana formations represent common minerals like biotite, hornblende and feldspathoids present lesser amount of sodium and potassium. CGWB (2013) reported that fractured and highly weathered jointed zones with 20 to 40 m in thickness and these aquifers having significant groundwater potential. The dug well yield about 100 to 250 m3/day and bore well yield 2 to 18 lps45.

caption.p: Geological formations map of the study area (modified after GSI 2020).
Geological cross section along A–B.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: The study area having lacks of comprehensive research on hydrogeochemical evaluation and groundwater contamination. In the study region, groundwater is the primary source for both drinking and irrigation and owed to such investigations play a crucial role for successful management of water resources. This study also helpful for water researcher and provides baseline information to local governing authorities. In the present work, total 60 representative water samples from various formations like (Buldhana = 09), (Chikhali = 21) and (Ajanta = 30) were collected during PRM (May 2022) and POM (December 2022) seasons from dug wells (DW), bore wells (BW), hand pumps (HP) and surface water (SW) at different locations with considering settlement, geomorphology, geology, drainage pattern etc. (Fig. 1). The study area map with sampling locations, geological map and geological cross section maps has been prepared by using District Resource Map (DRM) of the Geological Survey of India (GSI) and ArcGIS 10.8 v software. The location coordinates were recorded by GPS (Garmin eTrex 10) for the base map preparation. Out of 60 samples: DW-29, BW-19, HP-11, and SW-1 i.e., Shiddheshwar Dam (Fig. 2). Groundwater samples were collected in pre-sterile 1 L polyethylene cans, proceeding to sample collection; these cans were pre-washed with distilled water. The water sample cans were sealed, labelled properly and brought to the laboratory for further physicochemical analysis. The physico-chemical analysis was carried out with standard analytical protocols of APHA46. The parameters such as pH, EC and TDS were measured infield by multi-parameter water testing kit (Aquaread AP-700). Further, total hardness (TH), calcium (Ca2+), chloride (Cl−), and alkalinity were determined by the titrimetric method. For Ca2+ and TH, titration using 0.01 M EDTA solution and Mg2+ is calculated by using formula TH-Ca (MBR)*400.8/ml of sample*1.645. For Cl− titration using 0.02 N AgNO3 + 5% K2CrO4 solution is used. Titration using 0.01 N H2SO4 solution + phenolphthalein and methyl orange indicator used to analyse CO3 and HCO3. Sulphate (SO42−) and fluoride (F−) concentration were estimated by the gravimetric method using spectrophotometer (Shimadzu UV-1800). Sodium (Na+) and potassium (K+) was analysing using flame photometer (Systronics 108). For the analytical precision, ion balance error (IBE) was calculated and it will be found within ± 10%. ArcGIS 10.8 v software is used for preparation of spatial distribution maps. Statistical analysis includes correlation (CA) and Principal Component Analysis (PCA) performed by using MS Excel, SPSS 22.0 v and R programming.

sec.title: Quality assurance and quality control
sec.p: In this work, quality assurance and quality control standards were rigorously adopted during water samples collection and its analysis. Groundwater samples analyses were performed by standard analytical guidelines of the APHA46. The key quality assurance measures, including standardized analytical methods, analytical grade chemicals (Merck) and instrument calibration and accuracy were maintained during the physicochemical analysis. To ensure consistency, major cations and anions were analysed thrice and the average values were considered. To ensure the quality assurance for ion estimation, Certified Reference Material (CRM) and blank sample titration were performed to lessen batch-specific errors. The detection limit, expected range and other data verification checks for water quality parameters were included. For the analytical precision, IBE was calculated and found to be within ± 10%. Moreover, analytical data was validated through statistical techniques like correlation (CA) and Principal Component Analysis (PCA), with accuracy further verified through external validation and interlaboratory evaluation. Groundwater quality for drinking use was compared in accordance with the Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS) drinking water specifications (IS10500:2012). Pollution Index of Groundwater (PIG) was computed using BIS drinking water standards and assigning relative weights (1 to 5 scale) to each water quality parameter based on its importance in drinking and human health.

sec.title: Computation of pollution index of groundwater (PIG)
sec.p: PIG is a mathematical index for grade the enumerating range of pollution via considering several factors based on their comparative classification in significant quality of groundwater by considering water quality parameters like TDS, pH and key ions. Many researchers have been used PIG technique to define the level of pollution of groundwater and surface water21,47–49. In computing PIG, the relative contribution of the concentrations of water quality variables in each sample was considered. It was considered on the basis of drinking water standards by BIS and this index proposed by Subba Rao21. Relative weight (Rw) was assigned to each water quality variables i.e. TDS, pH and key ions, considering their importance in drinking persistence. The value of Rw differs among 1 to 5 (1 is indicating less importance in health risk hazard due to low pollution; while, 5 is partaking as higher importance for health). We have allocated highest weight of 5 for TH, pH and NO3 and lowest weight allotted to Cl that is 1 (Table 1). PIG is computed by the subsequent Eqs. (1–4):

where Wp = weight parameter; Rw = relative weight of each parameter; ∑ Rw = entire relative weight; Sc = concentration status; C = concentration of each groundwater sample; Ds = drinking water standards; Ow = overall water quality and ∑Ow = summation of all values of overall water quality. PIG values are classified as: insignificant pollution (values < 1.0); low pollution (1–1.5); moderate pollution (1.5–2); high pollution (2–2.5) and very high pollution (> 2.5) further used to classify the groundwater samples (Table 3).

caption.p: PIG computation with assigned relative weights and BIS drinking standards.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: The statistical summary of physico-chemical analysis for PRM and POM seasons and its comparisons with BIS drinking standards are represented in Table 2. The physico-chemical analysis data for pre-monsoon and post monsoon seasons of 2022 are provided as supplementary data (Tables 1 and 2). Also, box plots for water quality parameters are represented in Fig. 3, which were associated with the drinking standard limits of the BIS50.

caption.p: Statistical summary of physico-chemical analysis for PRM and POM seasons and comparison with BIS 2012 drinking standards.

table-wrap-foot.p: pH is on scale, EC in uS/cm and remaining parameters in mg/l (Permissible limit: PL, Desirable limit: DL).

sec.p: pH values varied from 6.9 to 8.9 (mean 8.08 in PRM), 7.74 to 8.56 (mean 8.05 in POM) (Fig. 4a) indicating neutral and slightly alkaline to alkaline nature and moderately permissible for drinking purpose51. It is observed that 85% and 98.33% samples are above DL and 15% and 1.66% samples are above PL which shows alkaline in nature in PRM and POM seasons respectively. TDS concentrations are range of 146.12–544.5 mg/l with mean value of 298.11 mg/l in PRM; while, in POM 168–1720 mg/l with mean value of 351.88 mg/l (Fig. 4c). Only 3.33 in PRM and 11.66 percents of sample surpass desirable limit, none of sample above PL. The mean values of EC are 488.65 uS/cm (250–837 uS/cm) and 642.85 uS/cm (318.97–2248 uS/cm) in PRM and POM seasons respectively (Fig. 4b). TH values ranged from 72 to 782 mg/l (mean 324.93 mg/l) and 66.62-1065.98 mg/l (mean 208.06 mg/l) (Fig. 4d) with 50% and 5% samples above DL and PL in PRM; whereas, 8.33% and 1.66% samples above DL and PL in POM season. Ca content ranges between 27 and 125.04 mg/l (PRM) and 16.03–196 mg/l (POM) (Fig. 4e). It is observed that 28.33% and 6.66% samples above DL in PRM and POM seasons and none of sample exceed PL. Mg having range of 18–61 and 6.84-91 mg/l in PRM and POM seasons (Fig. 4f). It is confirmed that 61.66% samples in PRM and 16.66% samples in POM seasons surpassed the DL; while, all the samples within PL in both the seasons. The Na content (Fig. 4g) and K content (Fig. 4h) vary from 12 to 59 and 6–19 in PRM and 9–86 and 3–36 in POM seasons respectively. It reveals that all the Na containing samples are within threshold limits of the BIS. Also, 18.33% and 6.66% samples exceed the K permissible limit in PRM and POM seasons. The anthropogenic and evaporation factors were primarily responsible for high values of cations in PRM and POM seasons and owed to surplus extraction of groundwater52,53,57. For major anions, carbonate (CO32−) having range (0–95 mg/l) in PRM; while, 0 (zero) value in POM due to the influence of dilution and precipitation. Bicarbonate (HCO3−) values in ranges of 140–680 and 100–900 mg/l in PRM and POM seasons and confirm their fitness for drinking (Fig. 4i). Cl values vary from 21 to 76 mg/l (PRM) and 10.7–125 mg/l (POM) and all values within safe limits of the BIS (Fig. 4j). Sulphate and nitrate values vary in PRM are (15–74 and 10–55 mg/l) and in POM (8-102 and 3–54 mg/l) respectively. All the samples are within acceptable range of sulphate drinking limit (Fig. 4k) and 16.66% in PRM and 1.66% in POM exceed the PL limit of nitrate (Fig. 4l).

The mean values for foremost cations (Na, K, Ca and Mg) are 29.85, 10.08, 66.53 and 32.31 mg/l in PRM; while, in POM season 21.77, 8.68, 47.28 and 24.89 mg/l respectively. The average values for anions (SO4, Cl, NO3, F and HCO3) are 67.61, 42.98, 27.63, 0.77 and 305.5 mg/l in PRM season; while, 22.37, 32.52, 13.91, 0.52 and 243.97 mg/l in POM season respectively (Table 2). In the study area groundwater quality are controlled by geogenic influences (rock water interaction, evaporation, weathering, erosion etc.) and anthropogenic activities (agriculture, domestic sewage) which leads to groundwater quality deterioration at few locations29–31. It reveals that pre sampling parameters mean concentration range is higher than the post sampling parameter concentration due to precipitation dilution. The nitrate and fluoride contents found to be excess in PRM season and low in POM season due to high precipitation (1097.3 mm) during year of 2022 which is higher than average rainfall of 750 to 900 mm in the study area with dilution plays an important role in groundwater chemistry. Nitrate contents enriched in groundwater due to use of nitrate containing fertilizers, domestic waste and compost. The phosphate rich fertilizers owed to increased fluoride contents in few locations. Also, the agricultural overland flow and decay of plant material affects the anionic contamination in groundwater51–56. The sample from surface water (number 55) is represent that water quality parameters are within allowable limit of BIS drinking standards and fit for drinking.

sec.title: Fluoride contamination
sec.p: The fluoride content is varied from 0.15 to 1.59 mg/l in PRM and 0.12 to 2.6 in POM season (Fig. 4m). Only 16.66% samples (sample nos. 1, 5, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 32, 52, 53) from PRM exceed the DL; also, 1.66% (sample number 51). In POM season, 8.33% samples (sample nos. 8, 15, 16, 43, 44) surpassed the PL limit. The fluoride in groundwater is mainly originated from fluoride bearing minerals (amphiboles, micas, apatite and fluorite) and phosphate containing chemical fertilizers and released through weathering and alteration processes. In POM season, F concentration in the central to southern-west region (sample numbers 8, 15, 16, 43, and 44) is more dominant as compared to PRM season owed to fertilizers and irrigation field impact on groundwater52. The elevated content of fluoride concentration in groundwater occurred mostly in deeper wells which lead to health problems like dental and skeleton fluorosis, renal disorders and nervous system impairment. The increase contents of fluoride in groundwater, where, groundwater seems to be slightly alkaline nature that favourable for the dissolution of fluorite mineral. Generally, fluoride occurrence in the groundwater owed to host rock weathering and monsoonal recharge water is the foremost phenomenon for the existence of ionic fluoride. In the study area, basaltic lithology is dominant coupled with the semi-arid environment, owed to fluoride contamination due to salinisation during drought prone condition and dissolution of secondary minerals in vadose zone. In addition, applications of phosphate fertilizers and pesticides in agricultural field have been argued as the sources of fluoride contamination where intense agriculture prevailed in the study area30.

caption.p: Box Plots (a pH, b EC, c TDS, d TH, e Ca, f Mg, g Na, h K, i Bicarbonate, j Chloride, k Sulphate, l Nitrate and m Fluoride).
Groundwater quality categorization based on PIG values range.

sec.p: PIG method is used to categorise the degree of pollution level in the groundwater of study area. In PRM season, PIG values ranges from 0.6 to 1.6 with (avg. 1.0); while, in POM, 0.5 to 2.7 (avg. 0.8). In the study area, total 120 representative samples from both PRM and POM seasons were studied for computation of PIG; out of that in PRM, 29 samples (48.33%) having insignificant pollution, 30 samples (50%) having low pollution and remaining one (1) sample indicating moderate pollution (1.67%). In POM, 53 samples (88.33%) are categorised as insignificant pollution, 5 samples (8.33%) having low pollution, 2 samples of each (1.67%) denotes moderate and very high pollution, no one sample from both the seasons indicating high pollution class of PIG (Table 3). Hence, it is shown that majority of samples (95–98%) having insignificant to low class of pollution in both the sampling seasons. Sample number 10 (PRM) and 16 (POM) indicating moderate and very high pollution located near the vicinity of agricultural field runoff and manmade influence57. The moderate to very high groundwater pollution concentration is located south western region of the study area in POM; while, in PRM low to moderate concentration occurred in central to southern and south-western zones from the study region (Figs. 5a, b). The south-western region shows maximum pollution as compared to other owed to low elevated topographical region. Due to the presence of Chikhali formation aquifer having pahoehoe dominancy of the lava flows in the central to northern, north-western and some north-easterly parts validate potable groundwater for both irrigation and drinking used (Figs. 3 and 5).

caption.p: Spatial distribution of PIG (a) PRM and (b) POM seasons of 2022, shape file extracted from SoI toposheets and modified in ArcGIS 10.8 v software. (Environmental Systems Research Institute, USA. https://www.esri.com)

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: In this study, statistical analysis includes correlation matrix, principal component analysis and cluster analysis were used to ascertain the degree of association among ions and their combine influence on overall groundwater quality.

sec.title: Correlation matrix (CM)
sec.p: It is broadly used to understand the correlations among major ions present in the groundwater and their collective impact on water quality. Bivariate plots are plotted to define correlation among the major cations and anions58. Correlation matrices for 14 water quality parameters from both the seasons are shown in Tables 4 and 5. In PRM, EC shows moderate correlation with TDS (r = 0.64); while, in POM season, EC and TDS correlation is strong (r = 0.85), also EC indicates strong correlation with TH (r = 0.90), calcium (r = 0.97), magnesium (r = 0.97), sodium (r = 0.96), potassium (r = 0.79), bicarbonate (r = 0.99), chloride (r = 0.83), sulphate (r = 0.75) and nitrate (r = 0.78), although with other parameters it shows low associations. Similarly, in POM season, strong association is shown by TDS with TH, calcium, magnesium, sodium, potassium, bicarbonate, sulphate (r = > 0.7) and moderate association with Cl and NO3 (r = 0.5–0.7). TH from POM season indicating strong correlation with calcium, magnesium, sodium, potassium, bicarbonate, chloride and sulphate (0.89, 0.90, 0.90, 0.81, 0.89, 0.73 and 0.78 respectively) and moderate with NO3 (0.68). In PRM season, Ca shows significant affiliation with Mg, Na, HCO3 and NO3 (r > 0.7) and moderately associated with Cl, K and SO4 (r = 0.5–0.7); while, in POM season Ca having strong correlation with Na, K, Mg, Cl, HCO3 and SO4 and low assimilation with F (0.28). In PRM season, Mg having moderate affiliation with K, Cl, SO4 and NO3; while, strong bonding with Na and HCO3 and low with CO3 and F (r < 0.5). Also, in POM, Mg showed weak affiliation with F (r < 0.5) and strong relation with parameters like Na, K, Cl, HCO3, SO4 and NO3 (r > 0.7). Na having strong association with K, HCO3, SO4, NO3 in POM and in PRM it shows strong relationship with HCO3 only, which indicating geogenic contribution in the groundwater by aquifer material, the moderate relation with K (0.66), Cl (0.52), SO4 (0.55), NO3 (0.69) denoting influence of agricultural inputs. It is observed that, K shows moderate connection with HCO3 and NO3 (0.64 and 0.56), this association due to inputs by rock-water interactions; while, K with NO3 having inputs by use of fertilizers in PRM season. However, in POM, K shows strong connection with HCO3, SO4 and NO3 and moderate relation with Cl, although carbonate shows very weak association. It is illustrated that HCO3 shows strong affiliation in POM as compared to PRM which indicating agricultural runoff is the indicative factor for altering groundwater chemistry. In PRM season, Cl and NO3 shows moderate assimilation; while, in POM season exhibit similar association with NO3 and SO4 (0.54). SO4 with NO3 in post sampling season indicating good assemblage (0.71) and with other like NO3 and F shows less assemblage. Similarly, NO3 shows low affiliation in both the seasons (Tables 4 and 5). The inclusive explanation approves that agricultural, domestic discharge from human activities are primarily responsible for increased TDS contents in groundwater due to process of influence of Na and Cl57. Overall, Ca, Mg and Na having good correlation shows geogenic inputs like water rock interaction and increased nitrate contents due to agricultural inputs52,53.

caption.p: Correlation matrix for PRM season.
Correlation matrix for POM season.

sec.title: Principal component analysis (PCA)
sec.p: PCA is the furthermost occupied factor analytic technique and widely used to understand the affecting physiochemical parameters and their combine influence on overall water quality59–61. Here, R-mode factor analysis was used to classify the hydrochemical data into different component groups based on inherent characteristics of water quality parameters. PCA performed through component matrix using extraction method for PRM and POM seasons and illustrated in Table 6. Total 14 water quality parameters were studied and considered for the recognition of major components that contributing the collective influence on groundwater quality. From PCA, total of 5 and 3 principal components are extracted from PRM and POM seasons. In PRM season, the PC-1 exhibited the dominance of calcium (0.943), sodium (0.909), magnesium (0.928), potassium (0.675), bicarbonate (0.896), chloride (0.642), nitrate (0.770) and sulphate (0.670) with eigen values of 5.889, % of variance and cumulative % is 36.807. Moreover, POM season signify the PC I dominance with EC (0.981), TDS (0.893), TH (0.943), calcium (0.962), sodium (0.958), magnesium (0.965), potassium (0.864), bicarbonate (0.956), chloride (0.816), nitrate (0.811) and sulphate (0.827), with eigen values of 9.304, % of variance and cumulative % is 62.027. It is exhibited that all these ions are enriched through geogenic inputs and similar findings shown by correlation matrix. This trend suggesting that groundwater is recharged with fresh water and the infiltrated water reacts with soil CO2 forming H2CO3.The intensive agricultural practices increase the alkalinity caused by HCO360, 61. However, other parameters like chloride, sulphate and nitrate are derived from anthropogenic sources i.e. agricultural inputs51. The PC-2 in PRM is positively loaded of TH (0.657) and CO3 (0.591) with eigen values of 1.838, % of variance is 11.485 and cumulative % is 48.291 shows dissolution of calcite mineral like carbonate, calcium and magnesium present in groundwater. Also, this PC is illustrated the hardness dominance due to prevalence of calcium, magnesium, chloride, nitrate and sulphate. The high positive loading of TDS is shown by PC-3 (0.836) with eigen value of 1.756 and % of variance is 10.972 and cumulative % is 59.264 controlled by natural factors like mixing of ions during groundwater rock interaction and it validated through Gibbs plot, which depicts rock dominance is major influencing factor for altering groundwater composition in the study area. PC-4 suggested the enrichment of F (0.786) with eigen value of 1.506 influenced by phosphate fertilisers like single superphosphate (SSP), diammonium phosphate (DAP), triple superphosphate (TSP) etc., commonly used in agricultural field of the study area. In PRM, PC-5 shows dominance of pH (0.559) with eigen value of 1.091 and PC- 3 (0.809) in POM is owed to aquifer recharge with rain water and influenced the alkalinity in both the seasons. In POM season the PC-2 is not suggesting the significant loading of ions. The eigen values indicate that if values are (> 1.00) indicating positive loading of ions that affects groundwater quality7,62,63. It is suggested that pH is increased due excessive usages of nitrogen containing fertilizer like urea64. In both the seasons, maximum loading of chloride and sodium is owed to domestic and seepage water65. Scree plots indicate the minimization of a large dataset into a set of water quality elements, which explore the groundwater geochemistry lacking most of the original statistics7,26. Factors show an eigen value > 1.00 were measured to be significant66 (Fig. 6a, b). Figure 7a, b explores the three component plots, the parameters like pH, EC and TDS are identical and originated from natural and anthropogenic sources and this behaviour seen in PRM and POM seasons.

caption.p: Principal component analysis for PRM and POM seasons.

table-wrap-foot.p: Extraction method: principal component analysis. a. components extracted. (Significant values are in bold).

caption.p: Scree plots (a PRM and b POM).
Component plots (a PRM and b POM).

sec.title: Cluster analysis (CA)
sec.p: CA is used to identify the diverse groups or clusters from the hydrochemical data sets on the basis of similarities within class or dissimilarities in various classes which impact on quality of groundwater19,27,67. It is used to classify the common influencing water quality parameters to distinguish the physico–chemical data raised on the original uniqueness of groundwater. Here, factor analysis of R-mode is functional to relation with the strong and weak associations amongst water quality parameters19,68. Different clusters are formed in PRM and POM seasons indicating which variables are more signify that influence the water quality14. The similar behaviour or characteristics of ions is shown by variable come under same cluster26. It is observed that the three clusters were formed in PRM (Fig. 8a); cluster-1 comprises of pH, K, F, CO3, Mg, Na, NO3, temperature, Cl, SO4, Ca associated with cluster-2 of HCO3 and EC. Cluster-3 includes TDS, HCO3, salinity and TH are jointly associated with EC, indicates that interaction of water and rock, silicate weathering and anthropogenic influence (domestic waste, chemical fertilizers) contributed for ion source in groundwater31,60,69,70. In POM season, cluster-1 represents joint association within CO3, F, pH, K, NO3, Mg, SO4, Na, Ca, temperature and Cl; while, cluster-2 includes TH with HCO3. Cluster-3 exhibits the association within TH, HCO3, TDS and salinity due to dissolution of salts. Although, cluster-4 includes TDS and EC is well associated with cluster 1 include major parameters like TH, HCO3, TDS and salinity signifying both natural (geogenic) and anthropogenic factors contributing in ions sources30,71. The cluster analysis suggested that groundwater quality in both the seasons represent mixed types of water that influenced through natural and anthropogenic inputs (Fig. 8a, b).

caption.p: Dendrogram (a) PRM season and (b) POM season

sec.title: Hydrochemical facies variations in groundwater
sec.p: Piper trilinear diagram is the plot of equivalent proportion of the major ions on a two triangular diagram (cations and anions) that represent water behaviour32. The collective information from each triangle is plotted on a diamond (kite) diagram and found application in two aspects72–74. It helps to hydro-geochemist for the classification of hydrochemical facies or water types based on the relative proportions of the major ions present in groundwater. Water samples with analogous chemical compositions, plot as a cluster on the piper diagram which reflects the dominant water facies which control water chemistry. The dominant elements are Mg, Ca and HCO3 and water facies are Ca2++Mg2+, Na++K+; HCO3−+CO32−, Cl−+SO42− found in the study area. In both the seasons, cluster of all the samples are plotted on the left-hand side of the graph which is above the 50% line of calcium-magnesium dominancy and below the 50% line of sulphate-chloride. This indicates that all the samples are confined to calcium-magnesium and bicarbonate-carbonate types of water. It interprets that alkaline earth (Ca + Mg) exceeds alkalies (Na + K) and weak acids (HCO3 + CO3) exceeds strong acid (Cl + SO4). Also, none of the sample lied on the right-hand side and therefore water types do not originate from alkali carbonate74. Carbonate hardness i.e. secondary alkalinity exceeds 50% that is due to alkaline earth and weak acids of entire samples with fresh water indication (Fig. 9a, b).

caption.p: Piper plots for (a) PRM season and (b) POM season.

sec.title: Hydrogeochemical evolution
sec.p: In order to know the hydrochemical behaviour and influencing factors (natural or anthropogenic), the bivariate plots were prepared for better illustration of their sources and contamination. The groundwater quality may alter by the geological inputs like water-rock interaction and weathering of rocks. The influencing factors are well recognised through different bivariate plots and all these values are expressed in meq/l (Fig. 10). Ca + Mg vs. Na + K (Fig. 10a) plot expresses that total alkaline elements are dominated over alkali. The high concentration of magnesium and calcium is associated with potassium and sodium can be accredited to process of base ion exchanges; wherever, the sodium is replaced by calcium and magnesium in groundwater at favourable exchange sights75,76. In both the seasons having positive correlation with R2 = 0.7008 (PRM) and R2 = 0.9158 (POM) among this plot which indicate same source of ions. Ca + Mg vs. HCO3 + SO4 (Fig. 10b) having R2 = 0.8783 (PRM) R2 = 0.9533 (POM) represent positive association which suggesting that these are favoured pairs of ions that found in groundwater due to silicate weathering of rocks11. Bivariate plot of Ca + Mg vs. HCO3 (Fig. 10c) signifying positive affiliation with R2 = 0.8544 (PRM) and R2 = 0.939 (POM) which suggest accumulation of additional Ca + Mg over HCO377. Plot of Ca + Mg against Cl + SO4 favoured ion pairs from geogenic contribution from water-rock interaction, ion exchange and mixing of different water sources in the groundwater with R2 = 0.4316 (PRM) and R2 = 0.8355 (POM) (Fig. 10d). The Ca vs. Na (Fig. 10e) scattered diagram shows R2 = 0.6629 (PRM) and R2 = 0.8408 (POM) having geogenic source like carbonate and silicate weathering which alter the groundwater composition. Na vs. Cl (Fig. 10f) scatter plot suggesting weak correlation (R2 = 0.275 PRM and R2 = 0.715 POM) is representing collective effect of both anthropogenic and natural sources i.e. silicate weathering and reflect weak interaction between sodium and chloride during dissolution in water11,78. The dominance of Cl (avg. 42.98 in PRM) over Na shows accreditation through anthropogenic sources such as agriculture return flows or domestic waste disposal and the dominance of Na over Cl (avg. 32.52 in POM) can be attributed to geogenic sources such as lithologically control76,79,80. Bivariate plot of F vs. NO3 (Fig. 10g) are falling above the equiline with very weak correlation with each other which indicate that non-lithological factors controlling the geochemistry of groundwater and represent independent source for their enrichment. Scatter plot of (Na + K) vs. (Cl + SO4) (Fig. 10h), ions are dropping on the both side of equilibrium signifying natural (silicate and carbonate weathering, mineral dilution) and anthropogenic contribution (agricultural runoff and waste discharge)20,25,81.

caption.p: Geochemical behavior of major cations and anions (a Ca + Mg vs. Na + K; b Ca + Mg vs. HCO3 + SO4; c Ca + Mg vs. HCO3; d Ca + Mg vs. Cl + SO4; e Ca vs. Na, f. Na vs. Cl; g F vs. NO3 and h Na + K vs. Cl + SO4).

sec.title: Control mechanisms of groundwater quality
sec.p: Gibbs plot is used to specify the mechanism of hydrogeochemical properties of groundwater that explains the association of ratio of major cations and anions against TDS33. This plot clearly indicates that rock dominance mechanisms with rock-water interaction and evaporation that control the groundwater chemistry in both the seasons. It is observed that only one sample (sample number 16) from POM season indicating evaporation dominance for both major cation-anion plots, indicating anthropogenic origin (Fig. 11a, b). The evaporation increased the salinity by Na and Cl that alter the TDS contents in groundwater. It is confirmed that groundwater chemistry mainly controlled by lithological domains and rock water interaction.

caption.p: Gibb’s Plot (a cation vs. TDS, b anion vs. TDS).

sec.title: Chloro-alkaline indices (CAI)
sec.p: CAI is used to study the variations in chemical composition of groundwater along its flow path. A Chloro-alkaline index gives idea about chemical process between lithology and groundwater, suggested two chloro alkaline indices (CA-I and CA-II) for the explanation of ion exchange amongst host lithology and groundwater34,35. Total 10 (16.67%) (Sample numbers: 1, 2, 8, 30, 31, 38, 45, 56, 58, 60) groundwater samples from PRM and 8 (13.34%) (sample numbers: 2, 10, 11, 12, 18, 35, 41, 48) from POM show positive CAI confirming base exchange reaction replacing between sodium and potassium with calcium and magnesium in groundwater for both PRM and POM seasons78. The negative occurrence samples show cation-anion exchange reaction occurs between calcium and magnesium get replaced with sodium and potassium in the underground lithological systems (Fig. 12a, b).

caption.p: Plots of Chloro alkaline Indices (a) PRM season (b) POM season.

sec.title: Irrigation suitability
sec.p: In the study region, groundwater is intensively used for irrigation; if it is polluted or contaminated which leads to reduce the crop productivity and increased soil contamination37. Therefore, groundwater suitability for irrigation is recognised through Wilcox plot.

sec.title: Wilcox plot
sec.p: This plot is used to understand the sodium hazards in the groundwater for arbitrating the appropriateness of groundwater quality for agricultural use (EC plots against Na%)36. This combination is divided into five different zones: (1) excellent to good, (2) good to permissible, (3) doubtful to unsuitable, (4) unsuitable and (5) permissible to doubtful with different salinity hazards (Fig. 13a, b). In PRM season, most of the groundwater samples fall in excellent to good zone except sample number 8, 21 and 50 having EC > 750 uS/cm indicating good to permissible zone for irrigation (Fig. 13a). In POM season, majority of the samples fall in excellent to good zone; while, a few samples (sample numbers 2, 6, 8, 10, 11, 15, 23, 30, 41, 47, 54, 56, 59 and 60) having (EC 750–2000 uS/cm) fall in good to permissible zone and only a single sample (number 16) fall in doubtful to unsuitable (EC 2000–3000 uS/cm) for irrigation purpose (Fig. 13a, b). Hence, it is confirmed that groundwater quality is slightly deteriorated in POM season due to dilution and agricultural influence.

caption.p: Wilcox plot (a PRM and b POM).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The present work has been performed through the integration of hydro-geochemical investigations, GIS and statistical approach summarized with following findings. The cation dominance is found in ascending order of Ca2+> Mg2+> Na+> K+ (PRM and POM seasons) and anion trend in ascending order of HCO3−> SO42−> Cl−> NO3−> CO32−> F− in PRM season; while, HCO3−> Cl−> SO42−> NO3−> F−> CO32− in POM season. Hydrochemical results corroborated that groundwater is slightly alkaline in nature. As per BIS drinking specification, all the water quality parameters are within threshold limit; except pH, TH, K, NO3 and F from both the seasons; moreover, it specifies that overall groundwater quality is moderately suitable for drinking. PIG results revealed that, (1.67%) samples fall in the moderate to very high class and located in south-western region in POM; while, in PRM season, low (50%) to moderate (1.67%) concentration encountered in central to southern and south-western regions, indicating anthropogenic contribution controls the groundwater geochemistry. The statistical analysis includes CM, PCA and CA explored that groundwater quality is mainly influenced by both geogenic and anthropogenic contributions. CM results inferred that Ca, Mg and Na having good correlation shows geogenic inputs like water-rock interaction and increased nitrate contents due to agricultural inputs. CA results depict that element sources of ions are of mixed types (natural and anthropogenic). PCA results depict that the ions like Ca, Mg, Na, HCO3 and K are prevailing from natural factors; whereas, Cl, SO4, NO3 and F are influenced by anthropogenic origin (excessive use of chemical fertilizers). Piper trilinear plot illustrates that calcium-magnesium and bicarbonate-carbonate type water control the groundwater chemistry. Bivariate plots signify that both lithological and anthropogenic factors controlling the groundwater geochemistry and influence the groundwater quality. Gibb’s plot specifies that rock dominance is major controlling factor of groundwater alteration; although, only one sample (number 16) i.e. 1.67% from POM, controlled by evaporation domain. CAI plots illustrate that 16.67% (PRM) and 13.34% (POM) samples confirmed that base exchange reaction and 83.33% (PRM) and 86.66% (POM) inveterate that cation anion exchange take place between Ca and Mg get replace with Na and K. Wilcox plot depicted that, 95% and 75% samples in excellent to good zone; while 5% and 23.34% samples show good to permissible zone in PRM and POM seasons respectively. However, only 1.67% sample is in doubtful to unsuitable zone due to excess EC content in POM season. In view of geological formations, Ajanta formation shows high polluted zone owed to low elevated area and compact nature of basalt. Precisely, the overall quality of groundwater for drinking is moderately suitable in Buldhana and Chikhali formations. These findings emphasized the need for sustainable irrigation practices and mapping of contaminated aquifers for drinking in the region. Also, it has practical implications for sustainable groundwater management policy, farming practices and awareness among public for health hazards associated with contaminated water. The limitations of this work include its emphasis on only a few significant contaminants; while, future research may investigate the trace elements and associated health risk, isotopic study and systematic groundwater monitoring plans and strategies. As considering sustainable development goals (SDG), it is recommended that, in future water-use methods and treatments are required by considering the climate change impacts and human-induced pressures. The findings of this work helpful to local individuals and farmers to manage the water consumption for drinking as well as agriculture. Also, it provides preliminary data source to local government authorities and budding water researchers to make comprehensive water managing strategies in studied area.
